5.45.text:
How do you feel now? I'm feeling a lot
better than when I first got taken out

11.03.text:
of the capsule. Yes the recovery
process is going to take some time and

15.26.text:
there's still a lot of vertigo going on
in my head, a lot of this kind of dizziness but it's

20.09.text: getting better and better every day.

21.65.text:
So yeah, I mean it's only ready just over
24 hours since I landed so

26.03.text: it's remarkable how quick the body adapts.

29.52.text:
You said a couple of times in
space that you

33.59.text:
you missed this feeling of crashing into
your bed after a long your work

37.34.text: Yeah. Do you have this today? Yeah. Did you do it?

40.73.text:
I did yeah and I got a few hours
sleep last night and it felt good actually.

45.62.text:
I did enjoy being in the bed. I
did enjoy feeling put in my head against

49.46.text:
a pillow. To me it seems a much more
natural way to sleep. I enjoyed

53.99.text:
sleeping in space, but I don't think I
ever got quite as good quality of sleep

58.16.text: in space as I did back here on Earth.

60.74.text:
First night on Earth, or first night back on Earth -
it sounds very, almost surreal.

67.55.text:
For you it was the case yesterday, who was this
first night

71.45.text:
Yes, I mean the first the first night is
great. The shame is really

75.29.text:
that everyone's so excited to see you
and you're excited to be back but you

78.38.text: can't fully enjoy the experience because, to be quite frank you feel pretty terrible.

83.63.text:
I mean it is, it can only be
described as something akin to the

86.99.text:
world's worst hangover in terms of
everything that's going on in your head.

91.02.text:
So it's nice that as the longer you
spend on Earth and you start to

95.30.text: recover you can start to enjoy things more.

97.40.text: The mission is not quite over is it?

100.30.text:
The mission is... I don't think
it's ever really over actually - I'd like it to you

103.97.text:
know to live on, as a good legacy
to be left behind. And it's like any

107.33.text: European mission we roll from one to the other.

109.58.text:
We've had some you know some great
success and Samantha flew very recently.

114.29.text:
Then myself and Thomas flying
later this year. So I'm already looking

119.12.text:
forward to talking to Thomas about his
mission and he will kind of... handing the

125.18.text: And just carrying on the great work that the European Space Agency

128.12.text: is doing on board the Space Station.

132.50.text:
So in terms of the science, this doesn't
stop though.

136.45.text: You've been doing experiments this morning.

138.83.text: And I believe you will do it tomorrow also. So what will your day be like for the next

145.55.text:
couple weeks. Yes so in terms of the
human physiology and life science

149.99.text:
experiments, they're going to go on for
the next year actually, in some cases two

153.68.text:
years for the bone density experiments
but certainly in the next few days

158.24.text:
that's a very vital period for collecting
lots of the data, as to how your body is

163.94.text:
readjusting back to Earth's gravity. So
it's already been going on. The very

167.90.text:
first thing I did actually on the
aircraft on the way from Kazakhstan was

172.25.text:
one of the motor skills tests - a fine
motor skills test, and then of course

176.75.text:
it's been blood draws, its been a
vascular echo tilt-table operations this

182.51.text:
morning and the days will just go
on. For the next few days, there will be MRI

186.50.text:
scans, for example, just to get all of
that data that we need.

192.72.text: All of this science is happening, where is it?

195.80.text:
All of the science is happening
right now here at the European Space Agency.

199.70.text: Here in envihab, where we are.

201.66.text:
So some of the experts who run
their experiments have flown here from

205.76.text:
the United States for example to collect
all of this data.

210.28.text: That's also a classical question people ask you when you were in space:

212.80.text: What are you missing, what do you miss the most

Now I'm interested to know if you miss
already something from being in space,

220.04.text:
from the Space Station. Is
there anything that you think I'm

224.36.text:
missing that now. I think I will, I
mean, obviously I will miss the view

229.31.text:
of Earth is the biggest thing. And it is
it's probably the thing that has the

232.58.text:
biggest impact on you and so it's quite
natural that should be the thing that

237.23.text: But also the routine up there as well, is phenomenal. We're in a very

240.74.text:
privileged position not just to be in
space but we are at the sort

246.68.text:
of sharp end of the spear where the
product that comes to us is in such a good

250.76.text:
condition because so many people have
worked on it, that we just execute the

254.72.text:
plan and that's a very nice way to
operate. You get up,

258.26.text:
you have a breakfast, you get to
work. You know there's no commute.

262.46.text:
Within an hour of waking up
you're working on board the Space Station

265.88.text:
and you're just executing this
product that is at such a high level.

272.09.text: Which is very satisfying. Very rewarding.

274.07.text:
Doing the science and you have this
incredible team helping you out

278.15.text:
so any problems that you encounter, any
challenges you might have.

282.11.text:
It's not just you working alone you're
talking to the ground and they're

287.12.text:
So that's a really fantastic environment
in which to work and that's what I

295.19.text:
do you take something for your future
life and career, is that something that

301.76.text: you say, ok this is a good way of working. Is there a model basically of the

306.29.text:
Space Station that you would like to
carry on having for your life and grow.

310.70.text:
I think it is very useful and again
kind of from a test pilot perspective

314.81.text: seeing it from that perspective, when working on the space station when

319.04.text:
things don't go to plan what you can do
is analyse it, work back and try

323.84.text:
and work out what where did that go
wrong, why didn't that go to plan and

327.92.text:
that really helps you in finding what
areas we can improve in and so that's

333.59.text:
something I'll take away, is
everything I've learned on board as to

336.89.text:
how to make operations even more

344.09.text: Ok. Now. We've seen you come back yesterday.

Sure I'll just talk you can cut

Yes, I mean there's a lot of
work that goes on even before that.

387.91.text:
We get into the Soyuz. We got
in about two thirty in the morning

391.70.text:
We didn't undock until five-fifteen so
even then we've been inside, we're doing

396.64.text:
the pre-undock drills. We're getting
into our spacesuits. Getting settled into

402.31.text:
the spacecraft and getting all the
systems up and running. But undocking is

406.00.text:
generally a quite an uneventful event
and there's not been many undockings that

412.33.text:
So you undock and the spacecraft does
too small burns to get it away

416.74.text:
from the space station
and then you have over an hour really

so there's time to read through the

what's coming up and even to look
out on that final orbit. The final last

433.24.text:
orbits of Earth to look at the window
and enjoy tha. But then from the moment

437.86.text:
that you do the deorbit burn things are
very busy and very dynamic and the

442.39.text:
deorbit burn is, you know, it's a very
serious occasion where it has to work

446.44.text:
perfectly and there are many failures
that could happen so... Who is responsible for that?

452.08.text:
Who does that? The deorbit burn actually if
everything goes to plan the spacecraft

459.10.text:
This is data that's been uploaded from
Moscow and so on the second the main

464.59.text:
engine will ignite and it'll burn in our
case it was four minutes 38 seconds and

469.15.text:
our job is to monitor that engine burn
and if the engine with a fail any point

473.17.text:
then we have to go into a redundancy
situation

475.81.text:
and try and get some backup engines to
burn. But then of course the deorbit burn

480.49.text:
is critical because that determines
where you're going to land on Earth.

485.05.text:
So if the deorbit burn doesn't go
to plan, your landing doesn't go to plan.

488.56.text:
And also in the worst case it could mean
up a ballistic reentry, which is a

492.64.text:
different profile a lot higher g
loading. So in our case it was it was

497.02.text: textbook. The deorbit burn went perfectly.

499.81.text:
And then you have a few moments where
the spacecraft is then just slowing down.

505.99.text:
It is now falling to Earth under Earth's
gravity and what you're waiting for then

513.25.text:
So this is where the service module and
the habitation module separate from the

517.57.text:
descent module. And that's interesting
because I'd spoken to some astronauts

521.83.text:
before and they said don't expect
that to be a quiet separation, you know.

525.85.text:
I've flown some Russian helicopters
in my time, and I love Russian engineering.

529.81.text:
It's very solid. It's very robust. And this is
typically Russian. I mean the thing blows

534.22.text:
itself apart with pyrotechnics and it's
no just one bang, it's a series of

538.78.text:
bangs. It's like a machine gun going off
as the pyrotechnics blow.

542.53.text: Actually you feel the jolts in the descent module as well.

546.52.text: As the habitation (module) goes away, it actually kind of springs off with some force and so in

550.48.text:
the descent module we go the opposite
direction. And from that moment onwards

554.47.text:
it's just the three astronauts in the
descent module and there's a slight tumbling.

558.43.text:
We're kind of in a reasonably
controlled tumble until we enter the

562.33.text:
Earth's atmosphere. Again I was
looking out the window. It was really

566.17.text:
interesting to see at that point, you
know, because we're used to such

569.80.text:
a stable orbit on the space station and
to suddenly find yourself in a

573.91.text:
spacecraft and seeing this tumbling
seeing the Earth changing attitude but...

578.71.text: So then you start feeling the gs well?

582.69.text:
You start feeling your body again? Well you 
don't really feel the gs so much.

587.27.text:
It is a very gentle tumble and so you're aware
of a bit of movement but

592.62.text:
it doesn't make you feel nauseous or
anything, it is quite comfortable.

596.97.text:
Then you start hitting the the top of
the Earth's atmosphere and the first

600.18.text:
thing to happen, as you start getting
that friction, is that things start burning

604.29.text:
off the spacecraft and I was aware of
sparks and flame coming past my window

608.43.text:
looking out. That's all the
multi-layer insulation.

611.30.text: So when you look at pictures of the Soyuz docked to the space station, you'll see all this

614.79.text:
material around it and that's to
insulate it from the Sun. It has to spend

618.48.text:
six months up there. So it needs this
protection. But that material is the most

622.38.text:
flammable material. So it burns first and
that kind of material, as you'd

627.15.text:
expect it burns in flame and sparks.
So it is quite impressive to watch out the window.

631.28.text: It is like a fireworks display. Once that's finished

634.86.text:
there's a moment there before the plasma
starts and the thing that struck me that

638.70.text:
nobody told me about was looking out the
window at that stage we're used to

642.48.text:
seeing the earth from 400 kilometers and
suddenly you're seeing the earth from

647.37.text:
100 kilometers and you're very aware of
this angle that you're coming in.

652.86.text:
You get the sensation of really
rushing towards the Earth and that is

657.78.text:
quite overwhelming. I was really
surprised. At this point I think we were

660.72.text:
all over Africa or Iran I recognise that
kind of colour of the soil. I couldn't quite

664.74.text: make out exactly where we were. Just to see us really kind of

670.56.text:
hurtling toward the earth and then the
plasma starts. And so you start getting

674.34.text:
this orangey glow outside the window. And
that's when the g loading starts to

679.65.text: build. Up until then there's really not been that much g loading.

683.28.text:
Then the g comes on fairly slowly just 1
or 2 g's and you get used to it.

687.96.text: Then it builds up to three and four.

690.21.text: I think we hit about four and a half gs.

693.48.text:
But it's quite, it lasts for quite a
long time and so you have to do the

697.62.text:
controlled breathing at that stage. You're
really pinned back into your seat and the

702.24.text:
things you're focusing on then, is
using the g to tighten your

707.04.text:
straps properly. Because until then
you've been in weightlessness and you

710.79.text:
you can't really tighten your straps. So
the g loading helps

714.15.text:
you to sink back into the seat and then
really to tighten up the straps.

717.89.text: Get yourself ready for everything that's coming.

719.89.text:
Is there a moment where you talk to your
crewmates? Is there communication outside of the

724.32.text:
operational communication inside the
capsule, do you share your

728.37.text:
impressions with your crewmates? No not
really because the... everything is

732.72.text:
recorded and so the atmosphere in
in the descent module is a hundred

736.71.text:
percent professional all the time. So
it's not like you're kind of

740.64.text:
having a great chat with your mates and
then transmitting on the radio something else.

744.12.text:
So we keep those
comments to ourselves and then just chat

748.17.text:
about that on the aircraft on the way
back from Kazakhstan.

751.05.text:
But it was phenomenal to
experience that you know the g loading

754.68.text:
came on and then got tightened up and
into the harness....

758.01.text: So how much time is there, from the start of the g loading.

761.94.text:
How much time do you know you have
until landing.

764.86.text: Well, the next event after the g loading of course is the parachute.

769.88.text: and that's the one..  you've got these timings and

774.50.text: so, we memorise the timings, we know exactly what's

778.47.text:
supposed to happen when. I had my
clock right in front of me so I'm

783.33.text:
controlling my breathing i'm looking at
the G loading I'm looking across the Uri's

786.87.text:
screen to see the re-entry profile and
where we are, and then just waiting for

790.86.text:
the drogue chute to open and that's
probably the most dynamic moment when

794.43.text:
the drogue parachute opens and i saw on
the clock the time went by and it was

799.08.text:
almost to the second that the drogue
chute opened. The capsule then swings

804.57.text:
quite violently under the drogue
chute as its slowing us down.

808.41.text:
What didn't happen is, a lot of
astronauts had told me that that lasts

813.09.text:
for about 20 seconds and the main
parachute and opens with a big jolt.

817.26.text:
I never felt the big jolt of the main
parachute. We had a very gentle parachute opening.

821.22.text:
But what that meant was I
was unaware that the main chute had

826.17.text:
actually opened. So this seemed to me to be
going on an awful long time and I was

829.68.text:
still waiting for that jolt. And I
didn't get the sensation that we had slowed

832.98.text:
down that much as wel. But I looked
across to Uri. He was very calm and

837.27.text:
collected. And I thought well that must be the
main chute open then because we've gone

840.33.text: well past the time that it was supposed to.

842.49.text:
And even then the dynamic phases don't
stop because once the main parachute is opened,

849.72.text:
we then have to jettison the heat shield
which is another big explosion of pyrotechnic bolts

853.90.text:
to get rid of the heat
shield and then the seats stroke into an

857.22.text:
upright position is your kind of brought
forward even closer to the console and

864.06.text:
and then you've got about 10 to 15
minutes under the main canopy until you

868.77.text: have the landing itself. And the landing itself? The landing itself...

875.53.text:
again, I was ready for... everyone talks about
this this landing and so you are ready

880.44.text:
for a car crash and you're expecting it
and to me then it felt normal

885.00.text:
it was a normal car crash it was no I
wasn't expecting a soft landing

890.97.text:
but the critical thing is to have these
shoulder harnesses absolutely tight

895.23.text:
If you... the problem is if you raise up out of
the seat and then slam back into it

898.83.text:
that's when people get injured so I made
a real conscious effort of getting my

903.03.text:
harness tight and making sure the back of my
neck was into the molded part of the

906.75.text:
seat and making sure that was firmly
against the seat. And then just holding

910.71.text:
everything in bracing arms and legs
inside and making sure your tongue is not between

915.24.text:
your teeth and just getting ready for
the impact and you do get a little bit

918.75.text:
of warning the soft landing thrusters
fire and it's a fraction of a second

923.37.text:
before the impact. But it's enough of a
warning but you're not quite sure when

927.03.text:
you when you're going to hit the ground
you've got the the search and rescue

930.30.text:
team from the helicopters are giving us
the estimates of our altitude and so

935.34.text:
we're listening to that, kind of
gauging when the impact is going to

938.34.text:
come but the soft landing thrusters give
you a fraction of a second before the

941.67.text: the actual impact on the ground.

943.74.text: You described... you voiced on life basically,

948.60.text: your impressions there, so I won't go into much detail.

952.30.text:
Yeah, one thing i didn't mention actually
on the re-entry is the noise of the

957.13.text:
wind which is really very striking
because the whole plasma phase and the g

963.43.text:
you know... you're just... you're going to
this reentry in your sink and you're

967.03.text:
seeing the plasma outside the window and
actually at some point my window just

969.64.text:
got completely burnt over and I couldn't
see anymore. But that's fairly quiet and

974.11.text:
then it's only as you get into the
thicker part of the atmosphere

978.01.text:
It really becomes very loud inside the

982.33.text:
been told to expect. And I'm glad that I

986.59.text:
to me because if you do if you weren't
expecting all of these things they could

989.41.text:
be quite alarming but that was very

992.41.text:
So you had this long flights. Bodo and then
we picked you up in Bodo, and you

999.04.text:
Saw your family for the first time. Can
you just say.. can you describe

1004.38.text:
what was that for a feeling? What is the
meaning for you to just land in Europe

1008.22.text: again, now your home is planet Earth.

1010.89.text:
But this is maybe in this bit more,
seeing your family, your parents.

1014.61.text:
It was really wonderful and
the other thing is it's quite striking

1018.15.text:
because you've been fairly isolated on
board you've been working with this

1021.18.text:
great team but it's by radio you and
you're only talking to one one or two

1024.90.text:
people by the radio as well. So you are
aware of this fantastic support team.

1028.80.text:
But it is quite striking after six months to
come back and then suddenly see

1032.55.text:
everybody. And to see that they
really are, you know, they're there and

1035.73.text:
they're supporting you. They've come to
meet you, and it is the middle of the night.

1038.25.text: It's you know three o'clock on Sunday morning.

1040.35.text:
And yet everybody had turned up to say
hello. It was really quite emotional

1045.24.text:
it was overwhelming to see everybody
showing such support and to see the

1052.10.text: Today I read this morning it's Father's Day in the UK. Yes. Did you get anything special?

1058.50.text: Well yes, I got a special hug from both my boys and cards. And of course from Rebecca my wife as well.

1063.31.text:
So that was lovely. But it was no,
just so nice this morning to...

1068.80.text:
We let them sleep through the night so
they could get a good

1072.70.text:
night's sleep. So they woke up this
morning and came running into the room

1075.25.text: and saw me there, so that was a lovely reunion.

1079.08.text:
Anything you'd like to add, any
statement you'd like to make?

1083.50.text:
I mean the one thing I've kind of mentioned there
but the one overwhelming thing I found

1088.08.text:
about this whole mission is the
level of support and encouragement and

1092.28.text:
it really gives you appreciation when
you're going through the training you're

1095.40.text:
aware of this huge machine and you're
part of that but it's not until you

1100.44.text:
actually fly in space and you realize
how much is everybody is working towards

1104.55.text:
you being able to do your job to the best of
your ability and that gives you a real

1109.14.text:
appreciation for what everyone on the
ground is doing and they're the ones who

1112.56.text: don't get a flight to space

1113.94.text:
You get to fly to space, so you work hard
of course, you're motivated

1117.39.text:
and you've got a huge incentive and it
just gives you a massive massive

1122.94.text:
appreciation from not only the people
who are professionally helping you but

1126.69.text:
that everybody who is really supporting
the mission in spirit as well so I'm

1130.17.text:
just very grateful for everyone for
doing that
